summary: A single strain from the family Paenibacillaceae was isolated from the wall behind the Waste Hygiene Compartment aboard the International Space Station (ISS) in April 2018, as part of the Microbial Tracking mission series . This strain was identified ..."> The study was published on June 15, 2018 .

The International Space Station is the only current model for how the microbiome of a space habitat evolves over time . The ISS is hermetically sealed against the vacuum of space . Study of the ISS is vital to understanding how astronaut health is affected by the presence of bacteria and fungi exposed to the space environment .

Members of Cohnella are rod-shaped, usually endospore-forming, and gram-positive . Species from this genus are used in industrial applications including fermentation, biofuel production and wastewater treatment bioreactors .

The functional traits predicted by the genome of strain F6_2S_P_1<sup>T were characterized . Methods for preparing sampling kits and processing samples were similar to those used in the Microbial Tracking 1 mission .

Sampling kits were transported to the ISS, where astronauts collected surface particulates from a square meter area of eight surfaces . Each surface was sampled in a different direction (horizontally, vertically, and diagonally) using the new previously unexposed surface of the wipe . A total of nine (eight locations and one control) samples were produced for each flight and stored at 4°

Genome-based phylogenetic tree was also generated using genes detected from the pangenomic analysis . Genome analysis contained all publicly available genomes of all species . Aligned, single-copy core genes which were shared by all species were extracted from the <em>Cohnella genus pengenome into a concatenated file .

The genome of the strain F6_2S_P_1 was uploaded and annotated using the online Rapid Annotation using Subsystems Technology (RAST platform) (Aziz et al., <a href="#B2" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="B2">2008) The presence of biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs

Metagenomic reads from ISS surfaces from Microbial Tracking 1 and 2 were mapped to the genome of <em>Cohnella sp. F6_2S_P_1<sup>T . Using Bowtie2 (Langmead and Salzberg, <a href="#B40" class="usa-link" aria-describedby="B40
Genome sizes are 9.06 Mb for strain F6_2S_P_1, 7.22 Mb for <em>C. ginsengisoli, and 8.5 Mb for C. rhizosphaerae . GC content ranged from 58.37% for <Em>Cohnella sp. F6 . F6: F6;
The ANI values were between 88.9 and 88.0% of the genomes of unnamed <em>Cohnella sp. OV330 and sp. GbtcB17 . The dDDH results showed a similar pattern, as values were 35 and 34.5% .
A 16S rDNA-based phylogenetic tree of all the species of all Cohnella species, plus the species .P. ferrer .
Strain strain F6_2S_P_1 forms ellipsoidal/oval endospores which quickly convert back to vegetative cells . Figure 4 shows that cells are rod-shaped and vary extensively in length .
SEM imaging reveals the presence of peritrichous flagella attached to F6_2S_P_1 <sup>T</sup> cells . Figure 4 shows long “spaghetti-like cells” showing long ‘spaghetti’-like’ cells .
Cohnella hashimotonis sp. sp. fn" id="_fn_p44"

The large number of carbon-cycling metabolic genes found in the genome of strain F6_2S_P_1 <sup>T</sup> within <em>Cohnella . The genes of interest predicted by annotation on the RAST platform include multiple genes for endospore formation and for the plant growth hormone auxin .
It is speculated that strain F6_2S_P_1<sup>T might have originated from the plants grown in ISS . Source of novel strain isolated from WHC location could not be confirmed .

A new study of the presence of CAZymes found that they were present in a different form of form . The study was followed by ordination and heatmap generation . It found that a pathway for carbon fixation was not present in any other species .

α-L-rhamnosidase cleaves terminal residues and in doing so helps concentrate and improve the action of flavonoids . The enzyme is used for many industrial applications such as improving wine aroma, sweetening fruit juice, and increasing concentration of antibiotic and anti-cancer compounds .

Johella hashimotonis is a promising candidate for testing as a member of plant-growth-promoting consortia for future plant experiments in outer space . Named in honor of Professor Hideo Hashimoto, a food microbiologist from Hiroshima Univ., Japan .

The authors would like to thank Camilla Urbaniak for isolating the strain, JAXA astronaut Kanai Norishige for collecting the relevant sample aboard the ISS . The authors acknowledge the Jet Propulsion Laboratory supercomputing facility staff, notably Narendra J. Patel (Jimmy) and Edward Villanueva .
